The Ring-inscription was a Black Speech inscription in Tengwar upon the One Ring
column2: symbolising the Rings power to control the other Rings of Power
column3: and perhaps being an actual part of its power.

column1: ==Description==
After Saurons first downfall
column2: normally the One Ring appeared perfectly plain and featureless
column3: but when heated in a fire the inscription appeared in fiery letters on the Ring.

column1: File:One Ring inscription.png
When Isildur had cut the ring from Saurons hand
column3: and so Isildur was able to transcribe the inscription before it faded. He described it to be of a Tengwar#The_General_Use "of Eregion"
column4: and the mode to be the one used also in Westron.

column1: Gandalf first learned of the inscription when he read the Scroll of Isildur that Isildur had written before marching north to his death and the loss of the Ring. When Gandalf subsequently heated the ring that Bilbo Baggins had found and passed on to Frodo Baggins
column3: leaving him in no doubt that it was the One Ring.

column1: Long before
column2: on the creation of the One Ring
column3: the smiths of Eregion who had forged the other Rings of Power
column4: heard in their minds the voice of Sauron
column5: reciting the words. They then realized his plans
column6: removing the rings from their fingers.

column1: ==Translation==
The inscription read:
Ash nazg durbatulûk
These words were physically painful to any Elves who heard them
column2: as any words of that "Black Speech" which incurred some of Saurons dark power on those present. When Gandalf recited them at the Council of Elrond
column3: the sky darkened and the Elves were pained.

column1: Roughly translated
One Ring to rule them all
column3: One Ring to bring them all
column4: and in the darkness bind them

column1: ==Ring-verse==
File:J.R.R. Tolkien - Ring verse.jpg
At some point following the gifting of the rings
column2: a verse was written among the Free Peoples regarding them:

column1: Three Rings for the Elven-kings under the sky
Seven for the Dwarf-lords in their halls of stone
Nine for Mortal Men doomed to die
One for the Dark Lord on his dark throne
In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie.
One Ring to rule them all
One Ring to bring them all
column2: and in the darkness bind them

column1: In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie.Some recent editions of The Fellowship of the Ring accidentally omit the first two clauses of this phrase from Chapter 2.
==Portrayal in adaptations==
1978: The Lord of the Rings (1978 film):
:The Ring Inscription poses a plot gap in the movie. Gandalf makes Frodo throw the Ring in the fireplace
column2: and later they both notice it is cold. The Inscription does not appear nor is mentioned
column3: although Gandalf recites the verse; all these remain without giving any explanation why the Ring was thrown in the fireplace in the first place
column4: since the non-existent inscription was not the point.

column1: 1981: The Lord of the Rings (1981 radio series):
:The Black Speech words form the "background" sound in various scenes about the Ring
column2: and Gandalf speaks them at the Council of Elrond.

column1: 2001-03: The Lord of the Rings (film series):
:In the book
column2: Gandalf mentions the Black Speech phrase in the Council of Elrond in order to prove his concerns about the Ring
column3: the atmosphere darkens and the Elves seem to suffer to hear the words. In The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring he utters the words while the participants begin to argue and shout in order to "darken" the atmosphere and make them stop. It is not mentioned anywhere in the context that these lines were the Inscription of the Ring and he appeared like as he was conjuring a "spell". That event was a bit controversial to the fans of the books
column4: since it was like somehow Gandalf made use of the Shadow in order to restore order

column1: 2002: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (video game):
:The Ring-inscription is found only on the outer side of the ring. Gandalf speaks the words several times
column2: both in Bag End and Rivendell. The Black Speech version can also be found on the cover art and disc
column4: it is written in poor quality Angerthas Erebor. A writer who was unfamiliar with the Daniel Steven Smith#Keymapping of most fonts simply typed "a-s-h n-a-z-g (et cetera)"
column5: so the runes read "l-lh-ng ô-l-e-s (et cetera)" in proper Angerthas Erebor.

column1: 2014: Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor:
:The words of the Ring-Inscription in the Black Speech are chanted in the opening cinematic and are quoted several times throughout the game
column2: especially when distracting enemies where the words "Ash Nazg" can be heard being whispered by the Wraith.
